question: Question_B_02_(d)
statement:
Let $A = (0,1,2)$, $B = (1,0,3)$ and $C = (1,1,4)$. Let $\Delta$ be the
triangle whose vertices are \emph{A},\emph{B}, and \emph{C}.

Find the point \emph{D} on the plane \emph{P} from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(c)}{part
(c)} such that \emph{A},\emph{B},\emph{C} and \emph{D} form a rectangle.
sols:
Let $\displaystyle D = (x,y,z)$. First we compute the vectors as stated
in hint one. These are given by

\begin{align*}
\vec{AD} &= (x,y-1,z-2)\\
\vec{CD} &= (x-1,y-1,z-4)\\
\vec{AB} &= (1,-1,1)\\
\vec{CB} &= (0,-1,-1)
\end{align*}

Taking dot products of these values as stated in hint 2 we have

\begin{align*}
0 = \vec{AD} \cdot \vec{CD} &= x(x-1)+(y-1)^2 + (z-2)(z-4)\\
0 = \vec{CD} \cdot \vec{CB} &= (1-y) + (4-z) = -y -z +5\\
0 = \vec{AD} \cdot \vec{AB} &= x -(y-1)+(z-2)= x - y + z-1 \\
0 = \vec{CB} \cdot \vec{AB} &= (0)(1) + (-1)(-1) + (1)(-1)
\end{align*}

It turns out we will not use the first equation. Rearranging the middle
two equations above gives

\begin{align*}
5 &= y + z\\
1-x &= - y + z
\end{align*}

Lastly, recall that the plane \emph{P} is given by
$\displaystyle 4x + 2y - 2z = -2$. Using this with the two equations
above gives

$\displaystyle -2 = 4x + 2y - 2z = 4x -2(-y + z) = 4x-2(1-x) = 6x-2$

and solving yields that $x=0$. Using this, the system of two equations
above reduces to

\begin{align*}
5 &= y + z\\
1 &= - y + z
\end{align*}

Summing these yields $\displaystyle  6 = 2z$ and so $\displaystyle z=3$
and substituting this above gives $\displaystyle y=2$. Thus the solution
is

\[\displaystyle
D = (x,y,z) = (0,2,3)\]

From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(b)}{part
(b)} we have that the triangle \emph{ABC} is a right-angled triangle and
so if we reflect along the hypotenuse connecting \emph{AC} we will have
a rectangle. We can achieve this by adding the vector \emph{BC} to the
vector \emph{A}. We have

\[\displaystyle{}BC=<1,1,4>-<1,0,3>=<0,1,1>\]

and so

\[\displaystyle{}D=A+BC=<0,1,2>+<0,1,1>=<0,2,3>.\]

Alternatively we could add the vector \emph{BA} to the vector \emph{C}:

\[\displaystyle{}BA=<0,1,2>-<1,0,3>=<-1,1,-1>\]

and

\[\displaystyle{}D=C+BA=<1,1,4>+<-1,1,-1>=<0,2,3>.\]

This point is on the plane because the vectors \emph{BA} and \emph{BC}
span the plane and this point is written as a linear combination of
these vectors.
hints:
First, let $\displaystyle  D=(x,y,z)$. Compute the vectors $\vec{AD}$
and $\vec{CD}$.

Compute the dot products with all four of the vectors from the hint and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(b)}{part
(b)} corresponding to the right angles. These are

\begin{align*}
\vec{AD} \cdot \vec{CD} \\
\vec{CD} \cdot \vec{CB} \\
\vec{AD} \cdot \vec{AB} \\
\vec{CB} \cdot \vec{AB}
\end{align*}

Notice the last one was done already in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(b)}{part
(b)}. Use this information and the plane from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(c)}{part
(c)} to get a system of equations that one can solve.
